item.title: [PI] 90% - 100% woodcutting || Perfection :p
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

[quote=“Int Bauk, post:51, topic:399252”][quote author=Server programer link=topic=496389.msg4172012#msg4172012 date=1354481282]
Thanks bro
[/quote]

y u bump dis?

this is also pretty horrid. bad naming, conventions, OOP, layout, declarations. you could also make use of enums.

also: case 1278://trees c.woodcut[0] = 1511; c.woodcut[1] = 1; c.woodcut[2] = 25; c.woodcut[3] = obX; c.woodcut[4] = obY; c.woodcut[5] = 8; c.woodcut[6] = objectType; c.getWoodcutting().startWoodcutting(c.woodcut[0], c.woodcut[1], c.woodcut[2], c.woodcut[3], c.woodcut[4], c.woodcut[5], c.woodcut[6]); break;

100’s of these kind of cases are making PI dirty. instead of actually declaring the log type, axe etcetera (when clicking each individual tree), above the switch statement just add a method such as:

if (Woodcutting.playerTrees(c, objectType)) { c.turnPlayerTo(obX, obY); Woodcutting.attemptData(c, objectType, obX, obY); return; }[/quote]

I agree this could be done better. Rather than giving all the information through the code you could just provide the information in the Woodcut class itself, call the method referring to the treeType and it would just gather info from there.
Wrote this so long ago so I won’t discuss primitiv programming code xD
I also forgot PI’s architecture so I won’t be much a help either xD

Read full topic

item.title: [PI] 90% - 100% woodcutting || Perfection :p
item.dc:creator: @Int_Bauk Int Bauk
item.description:
@Int_Bauk wrote:

Server programer:

Thanks bro

y u bump dis?

this is also pretty horrid. bad naming, conventions, OOP, layout, declarations. you could also make use of enums.

also: case 1278://trees c.woodcut[0] = 1511; c.woodcut[1] = 1; c.woodcut[2] = 25; c.woodcut[3] = obX; c.woodcut[4] = obY; c.woodcut[5] = 8; c.woodcut[6] = objectType; c.getWoodcutting().startWoodcutting(c.woodcut[0], c.woodcut[1], c.woodcut[2], c.woodcut[3], c.woodcut[4], c.woodcut[5], c.woodcut[6]); break;

100’s of these kind of cases are making PI dirty. instead of actually declaring the log type, axe etcetera (when clicking each individual tree), above the switch statement just add a method such as:

if (Woodcutting.playerTrees(c, objectType)) { c.turnPlayerTo(obX, obY); Woodcutting.attemptData(c, objectType, obX, obY); return; }
